Reality in FL Setting: Clients' hardware varies significantly. More pronounced in the cross-device setting than the cross-silo setting.
Resulting Challenge: FedNAS methods need to be heterogeneity-aware, otherwise the search will be delayed by low end devices or leave high end devices waiting in idle most of the time.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Every worker node can access all training data.
Reality in FL Setting: Clients can only access their local data.
Resulting Challenge: FedNAS methods need to balance searching for a global architecture suited to most clients’ data or search for architectures personalized to each client’s data.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Training data is gathered at a central location.
Reality in FL Setting: Training data is distributed unevenly across clients
Resulting Challenge: Since some clients have more data than others, FedNAS methods need to ensure they are not overrepresented in the searched architecture.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: The training data is drawn from the same distribution.
Reality in FL Setting: Each client draws training data from their own distribution.
Resulting Challenge: FedNAS need to be robust w.r.t. to non-i.i.d. data, which makes evaluating and ranking candidate architectures noisier than in the centralized setting.

Reality in FL Setting: Some clients are more frequently available than others.
Resulting Challenge: FedNAS methods must prevent the search from being dominated by the most frequently available clients, otherwise the resulting architecture will be biased towards them.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Worker nodes communicate over high-bandwidth, low-latency links.
Reality in FL Setting: Clients typically communicate with the central server with high latency and low bandwidth.
Resulting Challenge: FedNAS must be communication-efficient, otherwise exchanging model weights and architecture parameters becomes a bottleneck during search.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Worker nodes are high-end machines with powerful CPUs, GPUs and large RAM.
Reality in FL Setting: Clients are edge devices with few computational resources.
Resulting Challenge: The computational burden required by a NAS method needs to be reduced or, units of computational work typically done on a single worker node, need to be split up across clients, making the FedNAS method implementation complex.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: All worker nodes participate in each iteration.
Reality in FL Setting: Only a subset of clients participate in each search iteration.
Resulting Challenge: FedNAS methods must ensure that a realistic sample of the client population is represented in the architecture search and deal with high-variance performance estimates, because candidate architectures are evaluated on changing subsets of clients.

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Worker nodes are inside the same trust domain.
Reality in FL Setting: All participating parties (i.e. the central server and clients) can consider another potentially malicious.
Resulting Challenge: FedNAS methods need to deal with attacks from participating parties, such as poisoning of architecture parameter updates during search or inference of client data from architecture parameters [TODO: verify that’s possible].

Assumption in Centralized Setting: Worker nodes reliably take part in the search process.
Reality in FL Setting: Clients can drop out of a communication round at any time and completion times of epochs varies.
Resulting Challenge: FedNAS methods need to handle client dropouts and stragglers, since interrupted or delayed evaluations of candidate architectures can slow down or destabilize the search process.
